author: john.jackson
title: Supporting Local Communities
description: How do we support the development of Cardano Communities in localities with booming blockchain industries?

f6_assessments.q0:
This challenge aims to stimulate the development of Cardano in locations with booming blockchain industries, which is a positive thing, but it does not clarify the criteria to define what "booming" means in this context. In practice, proposals from different regions of the planet will be able to submit in this challenge setting. How to measure or weigh which locality has a booming and which doesn't?

Development of local communities is important due to the wide variety of social, economic and political aspects in different regions of the planet, but there is not enough information to clearly understand how important this challenge setting is for the Cardano mission.

There is a similar challenge that has already obtained funds in several Catalyst Funds called Scale-UP Cardano Community Hubs and seems to have the same purpose, but with a much more detailed context that allows us to understand the magnitude for Cardano.

https://cardano.ideascale.com/a/dtd/414312-48088

I would recommend that the proposer of this challenge setting provide more details like the example above.

This challenge setting is in line with items 1 and 3 of the Catalyst Fund9 Challenge Setting Strategic Goals mentioned in the Proposal Assessor Guide.
f6_assessments.q1:
Cardano has a very distributed community in different regions, it is one of the most engaged blockchains, probably the third most engaged, if we consider the number of members on social media such as Reddit and Twitter. This means that there are people with different financial, political and social backgrounds in different regions of the world, which is an upside to understand that the community has the capacity to address this challenge setting.

As I mentioned in the alignment rationale, challenges aimed at developing local solutions have already been present in some Catalyst Funds, mainly through the Scale-UP Cardano Community Hubs challenge that has already been present in 4 previous Catalyst Funds and has shown a reasonable demand for proposals by the Cardano community. Due to the great similarity between the concept of the two challenges, I believe that the demand can be projected based on the demand of the Scale-UP Cardano Community Hubs challenge, which in Fund 8 had $500,000 USD of available budget and had about $1.6M USD in total budgets. requested among 70 proposals, a moderate demand in relation to the other challenge settings.

One point that makes it difficult to assess feasibility is that this challenge setting contains very few details, does not provide potential directions and clarity to adequately understand how the community can address the challenge.
f6_assessments.q2:
The definition of success is subjective and does not help to assess the outcome of this challenge setting.

3 bullet points were defined as the definition of success:

"Involvement of business and non-profit sectors as use case owners" This definition doesn't bring the notion of magnitude. What kind of involvement? How much involvement?

"Developer community" doesn't say much, it's not understandable to use this definition of success.

"High participation in Catalyst" How high? And how does participation in Catalyst relate to local communities and the theme of this challenge setting exactly?


The key metrics are also insufficient to allow an assessment of this challenge setting, they are subjective and inappropriate to indicate quantity, quality and variety of solutions created through the challenge.
 
I would recommend establishing a time frame for defining success and key metrics

f6_assessments.q0:
The challenge asks, how do we support the development of Cardano communities. Specifically aimed at locations with booming blockchain industries. It is stated that regions with a critical mass will create the adoption of blockchain technologies, and Cardano will benefit from a strong presence.

I agree that strong presence and active community of Cardano in general is an important part of adoption and development.

The proposer mentioned “Regions with a critical mass", and that some regions create concentrations of blockchain and adjacent industries. I suggest attaching some information about these specific places. This way, future challenge proposers will have better understanding of what is expected of this challenge. The challenge reads as if it is imperative to act within these places.
I recommend editing the challenge setting and include more detailed information, to be able to make it a strong and successful platform for collaboration.
f6_assessments.q1:
Challenges of such a format, like developing local community hubs, have reached successful projects in the past funding rounds. Thus, the Cardano community has the capacity to address this challenge, if the changes are made that can create a better understanding of the success metrics and KPIs.
The proposal budget set for 500k Ada. No further insight on the budget side; if and how is reflecting the requirements of the challenge. I cannot say that it does, because as mentioned before, this challenge needs more information and editing.
f6_assessments.q2:
Success metrics and KPIs need an overhaul!
Under, "what does success look like?"; I suggest changing the first bullet point, that is difficult to understand. What does it mean for business and non-profit sectors, to be involved as use case owners? Or this point requires more clarification on information, as pointed out before.
The next two bullet points, developer community and high participation in Catalyst. I propose evolving on these ideas, and present more details of what would these goals look like when reached.
KPIs also require more clarifications. It is just mentioned as before, the Catalyst participation set as key metric is not enough to be an intrinsic metric for success under this challenge. This requires more specific details that can be taken as an KPI.
For the KPI, "Change in number of projects in region", it is necessary to define what a region is. To be able to create such a measure it should be clearly stated what defines some area as fixed, or unique.

f6_assessments.q0: The goal of this challenge proposal is to support Cardano communities in places where there blockchain industry is ‘booming’. This challenge proposal, in my opinion, is lacking information. It is not clear what is the definition of ‘booming localities’ and why there should be a separate challenge for them, since places where the blockchain industry is more active have less need for a specific challenge in comparison to places where the level of development is lower. Also, supporting these places contributes to centralization, instead of decentralization. Since this challenge proposal is not well defined, it is difficult to assess its aligment with the goals stated in Cardano’s mission for Fund 10. Since the idea behind the proposal might address some of them, even if the proposal itself is not well written, I will give a 2 starts rating for the alignment of this challenge proposal.
f6_assessments.q1: Places where the blockchain industry is already set usually have enough competent people to execute proposals, but the issue with this proposal is, in my opinion, that these places are already receive a lot of funding. The challenge brief does not mention any potential projects and directions, which would facilitate assessment if the community could address these challenges or not. And as said previously, it is not clear what is the definition of ‘booming localities’ so it’s not possible to assess if this is feasible or not. The proposal should be re-written with more information to make it possible to properly assess it.
f6_assessments.q2: There are 3 KPIs presented, and I’ll address each one individually: 1) “Change in number of projects in region”. This number is very broad, and it should be correlated to the projects submitted in the challenge, not overall projects in region. And, as mentioned previously, the region is not well defined. 2) “Catalyst participation”. This, I believe, is related to the number of people onboarded in Catalyst through the projects funded in this challenge. This might be the easiest KPI to track among all 3, but not directly related to any of Cardano’s goals for Fund 10. 3) “Referrals to skills acquisition”. This is not clear to me I don’t understand why it was included here. As other aspects of this proposal, I believe there is not enough information available to understand the challenge proposal and based on the available information, I believe the success of this challenge cannot be verified.

f6_assessments.q0: The purpose of this challenge is to propose a new iteration of challenges with a focus on building local communities. It is argued that a greater focus and budget should be allocated to projects that seek to establish or strengthen Cardano's presence in local communities with a booming blockchain industry. In spite of the fact that the intention of the author of the proposals can be understood, there are no valid criteria, at least provided within the challenge setting, allowing the identification of such communities. In order to have a clearer understanding of the geographical areas mentioned by the author, I decided to use the presence of startup concentrations as a criterion. As a reference the article presented in StartUs Insights (shorturl.at/dxAHW) who made and analysis of the geographic distribution of global activity in the blockchain startup field and found that the top 5 hubs (in terms of number of startups) are Silicon Valley, London, New York City, Singapore, and L.A. They are home to 1,061 startups and account for 34% of global startup activity. Other hubs would be Toronto, Paris, Zug, Hong Kong and Amsterdam to complete the top 10. A perfect example of the author's argument is the impact Cardano had on the recent Consensus 2022 in Austin, Texas, from which I can infer an indirect connection with Cardano's mision. As well as meeting one of the four strategic metrics we have for the next fund.
f6_assessments.q1: Although the focus of this project is to establish some blockchain hubs in these cities that will allow Cardano to be exposed to a wider audience and enhance its synergy with a demographic segment of society that has a passion for everything blockchain-related. Catalyst has had challenges focused on community building since its inception, so while this is a relatively new approach, I do not see any impediments that indicate the community does not have the capacity to respond or any limitations. Based on the data available on historical Catalyst funding, I cannot find sufficient proposals seeking funding to build in these major cities, except for Japan. Tokyo may not appear in the list of major cities mentioned in the reference article, but it may qualify for this type of challenge. Taking into account my previous argument, and the fact that a budget of $500,000 is requested, which represents almost 4% of the total funding available for the next fund, I assign a score of 4.
f6_assessments.q2: The description of success is ambiguous, for example, what is meant by "developer community"? In case this challenge is chosen for the next fund, I don't think that the definition of the metrics will be a problem for future proposers, because from my experience, the expected metrics should not be highly technical and easily verifiable. Unfortunately, they present a very generic set of metrics, making them difficult to measure and without a clear focus. Fortunately, the challenge brief includes some questions that can be used as a guide. To offer a guide to proposers at the time of the co-creation of the proposals, I recommend that they be accompanied by a list of possible expected directions.

f6_assessments.q0: Cardano is the blockchain that best exemplifies a healthy community in the cryptosphere. It is a natural extension of this community to engage in external communities and promote healthy interactions and principled adoption. This challenge not only aligns with the four strategic goals of fund 9, but with the ethos and mission of the Cardano community. Mutual support is the best path forward.
f6_assessments.q1: Cardano enthusiasts already achieve many of the measurable KPIs in their daily interactions, therefore it is evident that this trend would continue in local communities with high adoption rates. Anyone active in twitter spaces, community events and meet ups, or even in discord, has witnessed the power of this community to transcend all boundaries and promote positive, mutually beneficial interactions regularly. We are already verifiably successful in these endeavors. It comes naturally to us. The exponential growth potential of community enabled by this challenge should not be underestimated.
f6_assessments.q2: The impact of this challenge setting can measured in various metrics, and a few more KPIs would prove very valuable in determining the quotient of success for this challenge round. Be that as it may, 2 of the 3 metrics indicated can provide a good degree of auditability for this community based challenge. The measures of additional regional projects and related Catalyst participation will provide a lot of actionable information.

f6_assessments.q0: Supporting local blockchain hubs is a good way to leverage the development power of Cardano's community. This challenge setting proposal is aligned with Fund 10 strategic goals #1 "Prepare a group of people willing and able to make contributions to the ecosystem." and #2 "Build real-world solutions based on the Cardano blockchain. "
f6_assessments.q1:
The challenge setting proposal misses some example of directions and proposal that the community could make. What do local communities need ? What main constraints are they facing ? 
This could limit the capacity for Project Catalyst members to make good quality proposals. Whithout information or insights about what proposals could be made in this challenge, it is uneasy to confirm that the 500kUSD budget is realistic.
I recommend to elaborate the challenge brief, tell us what threatens or limits local blockchain hub's sustainability.
f6_assessments.q2:
As already said in feasibility section : the scope of this challenge setting proposal is a little bit wide and unprecise. Measure of success of potential proposals is "change in number of projects in region" or "Catalyst participation". What is a "region", what size ? how would the number of projects created by region by measured ? 
These questions are guide towards the refinement of challenge metrics : they need to enable assessment of impact of the proposals within the challenge, thus enabling a comparison between proposals.

f6_assessments.q0:
Growing community support has always been one of the important goals of Catalyst and Cardano. The new proposal only raises the challenge of community support at the localize level, so what is the definition of localize? This is not clearly described in the proposal.
Each area level will have its own level of impact on the community. So it is suggested to clarify this point more because now each fund has its own scaling challenges, community support for each region around the world.
f6_assessments.q1:
The goal and direction of the proposal for supporting local communites are not clear and detailed.
Let me give an example: If this proposal becomes a challenge in fund 10 and there will be many proposals to support the community of
1 area A is submitted while 1 community development challenge area A is also present in fund 10. This leads to infeasible for both challenges and a waste of budget. My suggestion would be to focus on areas that haven't received much attention at Catalyst in at least the last 3 funds.
f6_assessments.q2: There are three main key metrics listed and all are unclear to measure. The hardest is number 3 "Referrals to skills acquisition". I really don't understand what skills the proposal wants to measure? And what will be the effect? The success of the proposal is also very low when the details of the localize level are not clear.

f6_assessments.q0:
The idea here is a little difficult to pin down due to the brevity of the proposal.  The idea is that in areas where blockchain communities are already densely represented, supporting the addition of the Cardano community would help drive adoption of Cardano and provide critical mass for collaborative impact.  Ok, I'm definitely on board with this idea, but as a proposer I would want to know at this point just what and where this critical mass areas are, what are their characteristics, do I live in one of these areas?  Unfortunately there really aren't any descriptions of such things here.

For coming into alignment with the Fund10 goals this proposal should be presenting information on what kinds of existing regions with blockchain communities it is talking about (does it have to be blockchain?  Could it be highly technical communities with blockchain principles like decentralization or interoperability?  Or what about dense locations like southeastern Washington State in the US, where cheap power concentrates several hundred petahashes worth of blockchain computing power?) Are there communities that embody opensource, like maybe San Francisco with the Linux Foundation?  Beyond just needing more clarity on the possible "where", there is the very real question of "how"... though it is presented as an open question, there really does need to be some vision presented here of what kind of approaches would lead to alignment with the Fund10 goals:  how do these community hubs help prepare contributors, what kinds of real world problems would they be addressing, and how would they be improving processes and tools in the ecosystem?

Because these are left unaddressed in the proposal, I find that I cannot agree that there will be good alignment with the short and long term goals of Cardano, except within the narrow area of adoption.  2 stars for alignment.
f6_assessments.q1:
Because alignment is shaky at best, feasibility really doesn't stand a chance.  We are looking for the suggested challenge setting to provide the means for supporting the proposers as they bring their ideas within its scope and adjust them to fit the Cardano goals through the lens of the challenge.  However what we are given are a few broad guidelines that lack specificity.  It is very hard to imagine how "Developer community" is a useful guideline.  The team twice lists "Catalyst participation" and again, there isn't much in the way of connecting it back to alignment.

Once more specifics have been provided for how the challenge is in alignment with the Fund 10 goals, from there the challenge team can craft guidelines, examples and inspiration to help proposers orient themselves and their ideas (for example, "Events that tap known opensource ecosystems like Linux OSS developers in San Francisco".  Because any proposers under this challenge would likely be lost without these kinds of landmarks, I believe it has extremely weak feasibility.  1 star only.
f6_assessments.q2:
The metrics provided are described a bit above, so I won't belabor them, but it should be noted that of the 6 provided, 2 are duplicates, 3 are so abstract as to apply to almost anything, and only 1 (Change in number of projects in region) seems to have anything to do with what has been stated in the challenge brief about the relevance of regionality to this challenge.  beyond that small point, it doesn't do itself any favors, as measures of change could be negative or positive....it is unclear if this would be considered a case of "any data is good data" but it definitely doesn't suggest an area of high impact.

Because the presented metrics are unclear and unspecific I don't believe any support has been provided to help proposers frame relevant objectives with realistic goals.  1 star for verifiability.

f6_assessments.q0:
This challenge is about establishing Cardano Communities. It is essential as it helps reach out to people to spread awareness about the Cardano blockchain and helps bring them into the ecosystem by being among them in their communities. Most of the people who are in Crypto have come through online mediums. However, many people are hesitant to invest in protocols they came to know online, especially when it relates to investing money. Hence, establishing community hubs and showing the practical way of getting into the Cardano blockchain by investing or participating in efforts via Catalyst will help bring those people into the Cardano ecosystem.

The language barrier is another problem barring the participation of the non-English populace. Many proposals in the past or currently in other challenges are presently addressing this issue. The people in many countries do not speak or understand English which becomes a hurdle to onboard those people into the Cardano ecosystem. Establishing communities with support in local languages will solve this issue. 

This challenge will help two of the strategic goals. 1) Preparing people who will be willing & able to contribute to Cardano, 2) Accelerate the growth of the developer & app ecosystem by bringing the developers who, in the absence of community hubs, would not have come to Cardano.

We cannot immediately expect the highest number of votes with this challenge, but over time this challenge will help bring more people into Catalyst who will be prepared to vote. Also, this challenge will act as a springboard for Cardano adoption, as it strives to bring people into its fold. 

The author asked a few questions in the challenge brief but did not provide the answers. It seems the author is not clear on those questions and seeking community help to address them. I recommend the author look up another similar challenge, ‘Scale-Up Cardano Community Hubs.’ That challenge is also working on establishing community hubs; in that challenge, the author has a clear view of the problem to be addressed, and that challenge is written very well. I am rating this challenge four stars as there is room to improve by providing more details, such as potential directions as mentioned in the above similar challenge.
f6_assessments.q1:
The Catalyst community selected the above-mentioned similar challenge four times in the past funding rounds. In Fund 8, when it was funded last time, the community submitted more than sixty proposals. Hence it shows the willingness and capability of the Cardano Community for this kind of challenge. 

The author asked for a budget of $500,000, the same amount as the above similar challenge. Unfortunately, it seems unreasonable due to the lack of potential directions and types of proposals. 

The above-mentioned similar challenge had a good challenge team in the past funds, which can serve if that challenge is funded or for this challenge if this one got selected. But as mentioned, the chance of the other challenge is more as it is written very well and has covered the potential directions which will help the community in proposal preparation, help the PAs in assessing and help the voters vote. Hence I am rating four stars as I agree with the community capability, but this challenge needs improvement.
f6_assessments.q2:
The author mentions some metrics such as involvement of business & non-profit sectors, developer community & high participation in Catalyst. Sadly, these metrics are vague and cannot be used to measure the success of the challenge. 

Regarding auditing or tracking the proposals’ progress or success, no metrics are mentioned by the author, nor did he reveal the potential directions or types of proposals expected here. Hence we cannot even speculate on the metrics to measure proposals’ success or progress. Given the above points, I am rating it two stars.

f6_assessments.q0: The prosperity of an ecosystem is not only in its growth potential but also in the number of communities that participate and support it. Cardano is an advanced blockchain, but it still has not received much support from users compared to other blockchains such as Ethereum, Solana or Polkadot... The main reason is that many users are not aware of how advanced Cardano is compared to other blockchains. Many local communities have heard of Cardano, but they know only vaguely about it. Therefore, it is essential to support these communities to fully understand Cardano. By receiving the support of local communities, Cardano can build and establish its position. The challenge "Supporting Local Communities" is a great challenge that should be used for the next Funds.
f6_assessments.q1: There are many issues relating to local communities, especially local communities in developing countries. From public health projects to educational projects, all are essential for local communities. The Catalyst and the Cardano community are also very interested in these projects. It fits the growing trend of Cardano. Many projects (sponsored by Cardano) about local communities will help more local people understand and support Cardano. As a result, the adoption of Cardano blockchain technologies will accelerate and bring Cardano many benefits.
f6_assessments.q2:
The challenge "Supporting Local Communities" has 3 metrics to measure, such as change in number of projects in region, Catalyst participation, and referrals to skills acquisition. However, I would like to suggest and add the following metrics. First, we can measure the effectiveness of the challenge through number of local people (in a region) creating wallet and joining Cardano by doing surveys. Second, we also base on 
number of local people knowing about Catalyst and Cardano through surveys.

importance: Regions with a critical mass will accelerate the adoption of blockchain technologies; Cardano will benefit from a strong presence.
success:
Success looks like:

Involvement of business and non-profit sectors as use case owners
Developer community
High participation in Catalyst
